{{Democracy}} {{Forms of government}}
'''Demoicracy''' (also demoi-cracy) is a polity of multiple distinct people (''demoi''), polity of polities. The term is derived from ''demoi'' (δῆμοι in original [[Ancient Greek]], plural form of δῆμος or ''demos''), meaning "peoples" and ''kratos'' (κράτος) meaning "power" (to govern oneself). It is apparently meant to become an alternative to [[democracy]], understood as power of a single ''demos''. The term is used mainly to describe the genus of the [[European Union]] ([[European Union|EU]]) but is also gaining currency in more general theories of democracy above state level.
==History== Philippe van Parijs used the term "demoi-cracy" negatively in 1998<ref>Philippe van Parijs 'Should the European union become more democratic?' in Follesdal, Andreas & Koslowski, Peter ''Democracy and the European Union'', 1998</ref> to refer to the existing state of affair in Europe and in contrast to "European demos-cracy". This is not the meaning of the term in mainstream scholarship today. Instead, the term refers to [[Kalypso Nicolaïdis]] original statement in 2003 that the EU ought to be understood as a demoicracy in the making, a third way against two alternatives which both equate the possibility of democracy with the existence of a single demos, either national demos (the EU as association of democratic states) or supranational (the EU as a federal state). In contrast, the EU is not and should not be conceived of as any form of state (federal or any other) and does not depend on the existence of a single European demos to be demoicratic.<ref>Nicolaïdis, Kalypso 'Our European Demoï-cracy: Is this Constitution a Third Way for Europe?' in Nicolaidis, Kalypso & Weatherill, Stephen ''Whose Europe? National Models and the Constitution of the European Union'', European Studies at Oxford Series, 2003</ref><ref>Nicolaidis, Kalypso 'We the Peoples of Europe' in Foreign Affairs, 2004</ref> Thus, the concept has both descriptive and normative aspects. It tries to square the circle between the common criticism that the EU is undemocratic (the ''[[democratic deficit]]'' thesis) and the claim that there is no European demos (the ''no demos thesis''), purporting that a demos is not a ''sine qua non'' for democracy and multiple separate demoi can effectively control the government and in that sense exercise [[popular sovereignty]]. Later, Nicolaidis refined her definition of demoicracy as "a Union of peoples who govern together but not as one" [http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/jcms.12006/full <ref>Nicolaidis, Kalypso 'European Demoicracy and Its Crisis,' Journal of Common Market Studies March Volume 51 No 2: 351–369, 2013</ref>]
==Philosophy== Nicolaïdis’s originally advanced the concept as an alternative to the calls of the philosopher [[Jürgen Habermas]]<ref>Jurgen Habermas 'Why Europe Needs Constitution?' in 11 ''New Left Review'' (2001). See also Jurgen Habermas & Jacques Derrida 'February 15, or What Binds Europeans Together' in 10 ''Constellations'' (2003).</ref> and by the former German foreign minister [[Joschka Fischer]]<ref>Joschka Fischer 'From Confederacy to Federation: Thoughts on the Finality of European Integration', Speech at the Humboldt University in Berlin, 12 May 2000.</ref> that a common European [[Cultural identity|identity]] must and should be ‘forged’. Instead, she argued in favour of a [[community]] which recognises its irreducible internal [[Pluralism (political philosophy)|pluralism]] and is based on [[mutual recognition]] of differences rather than shared values as Habermas would have it. While both sides of the debate premise their argument on some arguable empirical claims (distinct ‘European’ values or celebration of tolerance respectively), neither of these is necessary for the normative plausibility of demoicracy as a theoretical concept. Currently many other commentators maintain that the concept is uniquely adequate for the age of interdependence of states and globalization of governance which should supersede the 'nation-centred' vocabulary.<ref>Jan-Werner Muller 'The Promise of Demoi-cracy: Diversity and Domination in the European Public Order' in Neyer, Jurgen & Wiener, Antije ''The Political Theory of the European Union''(2010)</ref> Perhaps that is why the term was latter embraced by some of the major proponents of deliberative democracy like [[James Bohman]]<ref>James Bohman 'From Demos to Demoi: Democracy across Borders' in 18 Ratio Juris (2005).</ref> and [[Samantha Besson]]<ref>Samantha Besson 'Deliberative Demoi-cracy in the EU: Towards the Deteritorialisation of Democracy' in Samantha Besson & Jose Luis Marti, ''Deliberative democracy and its discontents'' (2006).</ref> (even if not by Habermas himself). With the work of the latter authors the concept gained currency beyond the EU-scholarship and especially among the [[cosmopolitan republicanists]] as the most promising way for realisation of [[transnational democracy]]. Bohman in particular sees demoicracy as an emancipation project. It is meant to avoid domination which can occur across borders (citizens of one state may suffer from decisions of citizens of another which are taken arbitrarily). As domination can occur also internally all oppressed groups may qualify as demoi deserving a voice in governance. Thus, Besson suggests a dynamic concept of ''demoi'', which comprises all those affected by any particular decision (and thus subject to arbitrary domination by the group of the decision-makers).
==European Union== With regard to the EU the concept has been criticized because it does not provide an answer to the 'no demos thesis' but merely disguises the problem of democratic deficit and forgoes the capacity of peoples to collectively control their fate.<ref>[[Peter Mair]], ‘Ruling the Void? The Hollowing of Western Democracy’ in New Left Review (2006).</ref> Yet the concept is certainly more than a euphemism or exercise in scholastic creativity – if the EU is qualitatively different from the nation state (and from the federation) it needs to be analysed in different terms as well. As almost all politicians and academics claim the EU is not and should not become a superstate, it would be grossly misleading to evaluate it in terms of a state. Indeed, it makes little sense to claim that the Union is not a state and in the same time to criticise it for not being a democratic one. On the other hand, if it is recognised that the Union, as a polity of its own kind is to be analysed in idiosyncratic terms, we face a problem of circularity – we face an entity which claims to be a standard to itself. Recognising that, Francis Cheneval and Frank Schimmelfenning propose to extend the moral constructivism of John Rawls to transnational cases: 'the inter-subjective beliefs about the moral purpose of the liberal democratic state do not only imply the normative expectation of rule of law and procedural justice for the fundamental institutions of international society. They also imply normative expectations of democratic government in a society of liberal democratic states. The inter-subjective beliefs about the moral purpose of the liberal democratic state will eventually filter through into the relational structure of liberal democratic states.'<ref name="euce">Francis Cheneval & Frank Schimmelfenning 'The Case for Demoicracy in the EU' (2011) available at http://euce.org/eusa/2011/papers/8h_cheneval.pdf</ref>
Thus they set out to derive abstract moral principles for a demoicracy and use them to judge the EU subsequently. Their principles apply to transnational as well as to national level, and they find that the EU is approaching these principle while 'major demoi-cratic deficits remain at the national level.'<ref name="euce" /> In spite of this optimistic result, there is at least one deficiency of the EU from demoicratic perspective and it is that the governance discourse is almost exclusively elitist. This is especially problematic as demoicracy is calling for even more involvement of citizens on issues of governance.
==Development== Most demoicracy scholarship is abstract, and very little has been done to flesh out what an actual demoicracy should look like. Yet there are few practical claims that seem shared by all of the commentators. The first is the reliance on networks as agents of democracy beyond the nation-state where discourses are not mediated by states or nationality. The second is the active participation of citizens in these networks so that they are involved in the decision-making, deliberations and contestation at every level. All demoicrats would emphasise the importance of horizontal relationships between citizens, organisations and institutions from the different ''demoi'' on issues of their collective governance or on the governance of other states. Rights and legitimate interests of citizens are not limited to their own demos/polity but are extended across the borders to what is usually considered internal affairs of the other polities and people. This horizontal relationship is what distinguishes a demoicracy from a federation where the internal affairs of a federal unit are insulated from external contestation at least horizontally.
Beyond these general principles however, few details of an actual demoicracy are spelled out. To remedy this, Cheneval and Schimmelfenning with a team of researchers at ETH Zurich have embarked on a project intended 'to map and explain the development of demoicratic institutions.'<ref name="ETH">The project 'Designing "Demoi-cracy" in the European Union' of the Eidgenossische Technische Hochschule (Swiss Federal Institute of Technology) Zurich. More information is available at http://www.eup.ethz.ch/research/demoicracy/</ref> A precious few examples of genuine demoicratic institutions have been identified by other researchers. Bohman celebrates the system of policy coordination through committees and agencies in the EU as a demoicratic mechanism.<ref name="ETH" /> This is noteworthy, as from the traditional, that is ''demo''-cratic, perspective the influence of numerous EU committees and working parties is quite questionable. In the same vein, Michael Buess reconsiders the interaction between the EU agencies and their national counterparts from demoicratic perspective.<ref>Michael Buess 'European Union Agencies' Relationships with their National Counterparts' presentation at European Union Studies Association Conference Boston, March 2011</ref> Another example of demoicratically interlinked institutions is the so-called ‘yellow card’ or [[Early Warning Mechanism]] introduced by the [[Lisbon Treaty]]. According to Vesco Paskalev this is an attempt to provide an institutionalized network which enables many ''demoi'' to deliberate together on substantive EU legislation.<ref>Vesco Paskalev 'Lisbon Treaty and the Possibility of a European Network Demoi-Cracy' (2009), European University Institute Working paper available at http://cadmus.eui.eu/bitstream/handle/1814/13005/LAW_2009_20.pdf?sequence=1.</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== For a comprehensive and recent evaluation of the concept and its various usages see Jan-Werner Muller 'The Promise of Demoi-cracy: Diversity and Domination in the European Public Order' in Neyer, Jurgen & Wiener Antije ''The Political Theory of the European Union'' (2010). * [http://kalypsonicolaidis.com/by-subject-area/ Full bibliography of Nicolaïdis' articles on demoicracy]

'''Employment (Equal Opportunities) Law''' is an [[Israel]]i law passed in 1988, that prohibits the [[employer]] from [[Discrimination|discriminating]] between [[Application for employment|job applicants]] or [[employee]]s on the following criteria: *Sex *Sexual orientation *Pregnancy *Fertility treatment *Parenting *Age *Race *Religion *Nationality *Country of origin *Residence *Political view *Reservist duty
Anything required by the character or substance of the position or job is not to be deemed discriminatory by the law.<ref>Employment (Equal Opportunities) Law, section 2(c)</ref> Prohibition of discrimination applies to hiring, working conditions, promotion, professional training or studies, discharge or [[Severance package|severance pay]] and [[Employee benefit|benefits]] and payments provided for employees in connection with their [[retirement]] from employment. The law was enacted in 1988,<ref>Employment (Equal Opportunities) Law, section 27</ref> and replaced an earlier 1981 law.<ref>Employment (Equal Opportunities) Law, section 25</ref>
The law further provides that, under certain conditions, provisions in an enactment, [[Collective bargaining|collective agreement]] or [[employment contract]] made in connection with maternity are not to be considered discriminatory. It also provides that any rights given to working mothers are to be given equally to working fathers, under certain conditions.<ref>Employment (Equal Opportunities) Law, section 4</ref> Protection from [[sexual harassment]] is addressed in section 7, which states that an employer shall not "act against" an employee who rejects, or opposes, any act of a sexual nature committed by the employer or by the supervisor of the employee.
Violation of the law constitutes both a [[Civil law (common law)|civil]]<ref>Employment (Equal Opportunities) Law, section 10</ref> and [[Crime|criminal offence]],<ref>Employment (Equal Opportunities) Law, sections 15-16</ref> and courts may grant compensation even when no material damage was caused.<ref>Employment (Equal Opportunities) Law, section 10(a)(1)</ref> In addition, civil proceedings can be initiated by an employee, an employee organization or [[civil rights]] group,<ref>Employment (Equal Opportunities) Law, section 12</ref> with special protection granted to the worker filing the complaint. The Israeli Ministry of Economy (formerly known as the [[Industry, Trade and Labor Ministry]]) is responsible for promoting the law.

'''''Englander v Telus Communications Inc''''', 2004 FCA 387 is a leading [[Federal Court of Appeal]] decision on Canadian [[privacy law]] under [[PIPEDA]].
==Background== Mathew Englander filed a complaint with the [[Privacy Commissioner of Canada]] against [[Telus]], his residential telephone service provider, for disclosing its customers' personal information to third parties without the customers' knowledge and consent, and for charging customers a two-dollar fee to have an unlisted phone number.
The Privacy Commissioner found the complaint not well-founded, citing a [[Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission]] (CRTC) rule that allowed a fee of up to two dollars for being de-listed. Englander then applied to the [[Federal Court of Canada]] – Trial Division for a [[declaration (law)|judicial declaration]] that Telus's policies contravened PIPEDA, and other relief, but the court dismissed the application.
==Opinion of the Court of Appeal== The Court of appeal held that Telus was permitted to charge a fee under the CRTC regulations for name removal. However, the Court also found that Telus violated PIPEDA by not gaining full consent when they failed to offer the option to have the name excluded from the white pages when the customer signed up for the program.
==External links== * [http://reports.fja.gc.ca/en/2004/2004fca387/2004fca387.html full text of Court of Appeal reasons] * [http://decisions.fct-cf.gc.ca/fct/2003/2003fct705.shtml Federal Court reasons] * [http://www.privcom.gc.ca/cf-dc/2003/cf-dc_030428_4_e.asp summary of Privacy Commissioner’s report] * [http://www.mathew-englander.ca/ Mathew Englander's homepage]
{{Italic title}}

{{Infobox EU legislation |type=Regulation |title=Council Regulation (EC) No 1206/2001 of 28 May 2001 on cooperation between the courts of the Member States in the taking of evidence in civil or commercial matters |number=(EC) No 1206/2001 |madeby=[[Council of the European Union|Council]] |madeunder=Article 61(c) and Article 67(1) of the [[Treaty establishing the European Community|TEC]] |OJref=OJ L 174, 27 June 2001, pp. 1–24 |OJrefurl=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:32001R1206:en:NOT |made=28 May 2001 |commenced=1 July 2001 |Parties=All [[Member states of the European Union|EU]] countries except Denmark |implementation=1 January 2004 |CommProp= |ESCOpin= |ParlOpin= |Reports= |replaces= |amends= |amendedby= |replacedby= |status=Current }} '''Council Regulation (EC) No. 1206/2001 of 28 May 2001 on cooperation between the courts of the Member States in the taking of evidence in civil or commercial matters''' is a [[European Union regulation]] in the field of judicial cooperation. It allows [[Letter rogatory#Taking of evidence|taking of evidence]] from one member state to another without recourse to [[consular]] and [[Diplomacy|diplomatic channels]]. The regulation applies to all the [[member states of the European Union]] with the exception of [[Denmark]]. The [[Danish European Union opt-out referendum, 2015]], which would have opted-in, was rejected by the populace.
Taking of evidence in civil cases prior to the regulation was done by either under the [[Hague Evidence Convention]] or by means of a ''[[letter rogatory]]'' (also called a letter of request), a formal request from a [[court]] in one country to take evidence to another in which the [[witness]] is domiciled. This formal document usually required transmission from the originating court to the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] (MFA) in the state of origin, who then forwarded it, possibly through various [[Embassy|embassies]], to the MFA in the destination state. The foreign MFA would then pass the documents to the judicial authorities in that state, who would then go about obtaining the required evidence. The evidence would then be returned via the same long winded channels.
This regulation enables a somewhat simplified route by allowing direct contact between the [[court]]s in the member states. A standardised request form included in the annex to the regulation must be used. This aids the process by being widely recognised by the relevant authorities. The regulation also contains various articles to promote the use of communication technologies such as [[Conference call|telephone conferencing]] and [[videoconferencing]].
==External links== *[http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:32001R1206:en:NOT Text of the Regulation] *[http://ec.europa.eu/justice_home/judicialatlascivil/html/te_information_en.htm Taking of Evidence regulation at the Judicial Atlas]

{{Multiple issues| {{notability|date=February 2017}} {{refimprove|date=February 2017}} }} [[File:Suomalainen sotilasvala.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Finnish conscripts taking their military oath]]
'''Military oath''' in the [[Finnish Defence Forces]] is taken by [[conscripts]] on a legal basis in the beginning of their military service. If the conscript is unwilling to take the oath, another option is to take the military affirmation. Before the conscript is to take the oath, he must be briefed on the rights and responsibilities of a soldier, as well as on the meaning of the oath. The oath is administered by the unit's commanding officer and in the presence of the unit's flag. The military oath used to be available only to members of the church, however, current legislation no longer makes such a distinction.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.finlex.fi/fi/laki/kaannokset/2007/en20071438.pdf | title = Conscription Act | publisher = Ministry of Defence | accessdate = February 5, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url = http://217.71.145.20/TRIPviewer/show.asp?tunniste=HE+6/2003&base=erhe&palvelin=www.eduskunta.fi&f=WORD | title = Hallituksen esitys Eduskunnalle laiksi asevelvollisuuslain 28 §:n muuttamisesta| publisher = Parliament of Finland| accessdate = August 14, 2008| language = Finnish}}</ref><ref name="Finlex">{{cite web| url = http://www.finlex.fi/fi/laki/alkup/2007/20071443 | title = Valtioneuvoston asetus asevelvollisuudesta | publisher = Parliament of Finland| accessdate = February 5, 2017| language = Finnish}}</ref>
Usually the military oath is taken after the basic training period or about seven weeks into the conscript's military service. Depending on the circumstances, the oath ceremony is held either at the garrison or at a nearby municipality. The aim is to make the event as ceremonious as possible. The relatives of the conscript's are usually invited to attend the ceremony. The ceremony also includes a parade, field service, equipment demonstration and lunch. After taking the oath, the conscripts receive the rank of private. The military affirmation is usually taken on the same day in a smaller ceremony. The conscripts who take the assurance usually still participate in the oath ceremony, but do not take the oath itself. <ref>[http://docplayer.fi/698745-Opas-saapumiseran-1-2015-varusmiehelle.html Opas saapumiserän1/2015 varusmiehelle] (in Finnish), p. 13, ''[[Gulf of Finland Naval Command|Coastal Brigade]]''. Retrieved on February 5, 2017.</ref>
==Oath and affirmation text== ===Finnish text=== Minä N. N. lupaan ja vakuutan kaikkivaltiaan ja kaikkitietävän Jumalan edessä (vakuutuksessa: kunniani ja omantuntoni kautta), olevani Suomen valtakunnan luotettava ja uskollinen kansalainen. Tahdon palvella maatani rehellisesti sekä parhaan kykyni mukaan etsiä ja edistää sen hyötyä ja parasta. Minä tahdon kaikkialla ja kaikissa tilanteissa, rauhan ja sodan aikana puolustaa isänmaani koskemattomuutta, sen laillista valtiojärjestystä sekä valtakunnan laillista esivaltaa. Jos havaitsen tai saan tietää jotakin olevan tekeillä laillisen esivallan kukistamiseksi tai maan valtiojärjestyksen kumoamiseksi, tahdon sen viipymättä viranomaisille ilmoittaa. Joukkoa, johon kuulun sekä paikkaani siinä, en jätä missään tilanteessa, vaan niin kauan kuin minussa voimia on, suoritan saamani tehtävän loppuun. Lupaan käyttäytyä kunnollisesti ja ryhdikkäästi, totella esimiehiäni, noudattaa lakeja ja asetuksia sekä säilyttää minulle uskotut palvelussalaisuudet. Tahdon olla suora ja auttavainen myös palvelustovereitani kohtaan. Milloinkaan en sukulaisuuden, ystävyyden, kateuden, vihan tai pelon vuoksi enkä myöskään lahjojen tai muun syyn tähden toimi vastoin palvelusvelvollisuuttani. Jos minut asetetaan esimiesasemaan, tahdon olla alaisiani kohtaan oikeudenmukainen, pitää huolta heidän hyvinvoinnistaan, hankkia tietoa heidän toiveistaan, olla heidän neuvonantajanaan ja ohjaajanaan sekä omasta puolestani pyrkiä olemaan heille hyvänä ja kannustavana esimerkkinä. Kaiken tämän minä tahdon kunniani ja omantuntoni mukaan täyttää.<ref name="Finlex"/>
===English translation=== I, (name), promise and affirm before the almighty and all-knowing God (in affirmation: by my honor and by my conscience), that I am a trustworthy and faithful citizen of the realm of Finland. I want to serve my country honestly and, to my best ability, seek and pursue her edification and advantage. I want everywhere and in every situation, during the peace and during the war, defend the inviolability of my fatherland, her legal system of government and the legal authority of the realm. If I perceive or gain knowledge of activity to overthrow the legal authority or to subvert the system of government of the country, I want to report it to the authorities without delay. The troop to which I belong and my place in it I will not desert in any situation, but so long as I have strength in me, I will completely fulfill the task I have received. I promise to act properly and uprightly, obey my superiors, comply with the laws and decrees and keep the service secrets trusted in me. I want to be forthright and helpful to my fellow servicemen. Never will I due to kinship, friendship, envy, hatred or fear nor because of gifts or any other reason act contrary to my duty in service. If I be given a position of superiority, I want to be rightful to my subordinates, to take care of their well-being, acquire information on their wishes, to be their councilor and guide and, for my own self, set them a good and encouraging example. All this I want to fulfill according to my honor and my conscience.<ref name="Finlex"/>
==See also== *[[United States Armed Forces oath of enlistment]] *[[Ceremonial oath of the Bundeswehr]]

{{primary sources|date=February 2017}}
The '''Florida Building Code (FBC)''' is a set of standards designed by the [[United States|US]] state of [[Florida]] for buildings. Many regulations and guidelines distributed are important benchmarks regarding [[Tropical cyclone|hurricane]] protection. [[Miami-Dade County, Florida|Miami-Dade County]] was the first in Florida to certify hurricane resistant standards for structures which the Florida Building Code subsequently enacted across all requirements for Hurricane resistant buildings. Many other states reference the requirements set in the Florida Building codes, or have developed their own requirements for hurricanes.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://us.allegion.com/IRSTDocs/Brochure/109459.pdf|title=Allegion Windstorm solutions (p. 5)|last=|first=|date=2016-03-16|website=allegion.co/us|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-02-10}}</ref>
In many aspects the Florida Building Code is similar to and is based upon the [[International Building Code|International Building Code (IBC)]] used in the [[United States]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.floridabuilding.org/fbc/q-a/florida_building_code_q-a.doc|title=Florida Building Code Q&A|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=Oct 9, 2016}}</ref>
The Florida Building Code, 5th Edition, released 2014, is currently the latest, with the 6th edition due in 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.charlottecountyfl.gov/dept/commdev/Documents/5thEditionFBC_UpdatePresentation.pdf|title=Florida Building Code, 5th Edition (2014) Update|last=|first=|date=June 30, 2015|website=|publisher=|access-date=Oct 9, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://floridabuilding.org/c/default.aspx|title=Florida Building Commission Site|last=|first=|date=|website=floridabuilding.org|publisher=|access-date=2016-10-09}}</ref>
== Hurricane Guidelines == The 2010 edition of the Florida Building Code introduced significant changes to wind load design, in particular the presentation of the wind speed maps.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.floridabuilding.org/fbc/wind_2010/flyer_wind_january2012.pdf|title=Changes to the Wind Speed Maps and Wind Design – 2010 Florida Building Codes|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=Oct 9, 2016}}</ref>
The [[Miami-Dade County, Florida|Miami-Dade]] and [[Broward County, Florida|Broward County]] norms, are both included in the High-Velocity Hurricane Zones (HVHZ) and contain more stringent requirements.<ref name=":0" /> Other counties such as [[Palm Beach County, Florida|Palm Beach County]] do not require the same HVHZ building standards for compliance with the Florida Building Codes.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sun-sentinel.com/local/palm-beach/|title=Palm Beach County News - Sun Sentinel|website=www.sun-sentinel.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-02-10}}</ref> {| class="wikitable" |+Risk categories for wind speeds in High Velocity Hurricane Zones (HVHZ) !Miami Dade County ! |- |Risk Category I: Buildings & Structures |165 mph |- |Risk Category II: Buildings & Structures |175 mph |- |Risk Category III: Buildings & Structures |185 mph |- !Broward County ! |- |Risk Category I: Buildings & Structures |156 mph |- |Risk Category II: Buildings & Structures |170 mph |- |Risk Category III: Buildings & Structures |180 mph |} Both Miami-Dade County and the State of Florida maintain web-searchable databases of products approved for use as hurricane protection. These typically include not only actual test results from certified independent testing laboratories, they also contain "Product Approval Drawings" or "Installation Instructions" which provide specifications for hurricane shutter assembly and installation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.miamidade.gov/building/pc-search_app.asp|title=Miami-Dade County - Building - Product Control Search|last=Services|first=Miami-Dade County Online|website=www.miamidade.gov|access-date=2016-10-09}}</ref>
Impact tests conducted on building materials are measured and tested via TAS201, 202 and 203.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://codes.iccsafe.org/app/book/content/PDF/2001%20Florida%20Codes/Test%20Protocols/Testing%20Application%20Standard%20201-94.pdf|title=Testing Application Standard (TAS) 201-94|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=Oct 9, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://codes.iccsafe.org/app/book/content/PDF/2001%20Florida%20Codes/Test%20Protocols/Testing%20Application%20Standard%20202-94.pdf|title=Testing Application Standard (TAS) 202-94|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=Oct 9, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://codes.iccsafe.org/app/book/content/PDF/2001%20Florida%20Codes/Test%20Protocols/Testing%20Application%20Standard%20203-94.pdf|title=Testing Application Standard (TAS) 203-94|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=Oct 9, 2016}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2011}} [[File:Bundesarchiv B 145 Bild-F010324-0002, Flughafen Köln-Bonn, Adenauer, de Gaulle-cropped.jpg|thumb|General [[Charles de Gaulle]], 20 May 1961]]
A '''referendum on the direct election of the President''' was held in [[France]] on 28 October 1962.<ref name=DN>[[Dieter Nohlen]] & Philip Stöver (2010) ''Elections in Europe: A data handbook'', p674 {{ISBN|978-3-8329-5609-7}}</ref> The question was whether to have the [[President of France|president of the French Republic]] elected by direct popular vote, rather than by an [[electoral college]]. It was approved by 62.3% of voters with a 77.0% turnout.<ref>Nohlen & Stöver, p685</ref> However, the reform was controversial because it strengthened the executive at the expense of [[Parliament of France|Parliament]], and because of the disputed constitutionality of the procedure used.
==Background== In the [[French Third Republic|Third]] and [[Fourth French Republic|Fourth Republic]], [[Parliament of France|Parliament]] elected the President of the Republic. In the original 1958 constitution of the [[French Fifth Republic|Fifth Republic]], the president was elected by an [[electoral college]], in a manner similar to the [[Senator of France|senators]]: electors were the members of Parliament, members of the [[departments of France|departmental]] assemblies, and representatives of cities, towns and villages (such as mayors).<ref>See [[:s:fr:Constitution de 1958 avec modifications#Article 6|Article 6 of the 1958 Constitution]]. Note that most versions of the constitution available online and in books are not the original version, but some later amended version.</ref> [[Charles de Gaulle]] was elected in this manner in the [[French presidential election, 1958|1958 presidential election]].
The presidential office in the Third and Fourth republic was largely ceremonial, with most executive power vested in the "president of the Council of ministers" (short: "president of the Council" or ''président du conseil''), a more powerful analogue to the present-day [[Prime minister of France|Prime minister]]. Charles de Gaulle, who largely designed the constitution of the Fifth Republic, wanted a more powerful presidential office. The proposed change would have the president elected by the [[two-round system|two-round system of voting]]; This direct election by more than half of the non-blank ballots directly cast by the citizenship would give the office much more legitimacy and status than indirect election by the presidential college, thus greater influence even with unchanged constitutional powers.
==Proposal and debate== :''See [[French legislative election, 1962]] for more about the French politics of that time.'' Charles de Gaulle soon preferred to be elected by direct popular vote, which would give him a stronger political position, and proposed that the Constitution be amended.<ref>See the [http://www.charles-de-gaulle.org/pages/espace-pedagogique/le-point-sur/les-textes-a-connaitre/discours-du-20-septembre-1962.php radiophonic speech] to the nation of 20 September 1962 by Charles de Gaulle, announcing the forthcoming referendum.</ref>
The referendum was highly controversial. Part of the controversy concerned the constitutional processes for modifying the Constitution.<ref name="Stone"/> According to article 89 of the [[Constitution of France]], any constitutional reform must be first approved by both houses of Parliament: the [[National Assembly of France|National Assembly]] and the [[Senate of France|Senate]]. Then it is either approved by a referendum, or by a solemn joint session of both houses known as [[Congress of France|Congress]]. Instead, Charles de Gaulle used Article 11 of the Constitution, which allows the [[Prime Minister of France|Prime Minister]], then [[Georges Pompidou]], to request the President to submit to a referendum a bill in certain areas of law, including "the organization of public powers". To summarize, supporters of de Gaulle and the referendum contended that Article 11 allowed bills to be passed on constitutional matters, while opponents considered that the existence of a special process in Article 89 precluded this.<ref name="Stone"/><ref name="conflit"/>
Many legal scholars and politicians disagreed with this application of Article 11, which they felt was unconstitutional, while [[Gaullism|Gaullist]]s generally supported the move.<ref name="Stone"/> [[François Mitterrand]], former minister and future President of the Republic, characterized the referendum as unconstitutional.<ref>[[François Mitterrand]], ''Le coup d'état permanent'' ("The permanent coup d'état", alluding to [[Charles de Gaulle]]'s presidency), 1966; later edition 1998, Julliard, {{ISBN|2-260-00378-8}}: ''Ainsi s'explique le secret de son obstination à obtenir par le référendum inconstitutionnel de 1962 cette réforme'' ("Thus is explained [De Gaulle's] obstination to obtain this reform by the unconstitutional referendum of 1962")</ref> [[Gaston Monnerville]], president of the Senate, referred the matter to the [[Constitutional Council of France|Constitutional Council]] (Article 61). The council however ruled that it fell outside of its jurisdiction to strike down a reform voted by the French people, thus upholding de Gaulle's action.<ref name="Stone">Alec Stone, ''The Birth of Judicial Politics in France: The Constitutional Council in Comparative Perspective'', Oxford University Press, {{ISBN|0-19-507034-8}}, chapter III</ref><ref>See [http://www.conseil-constitutionnel.fr/conseil-constitutionnel/francais/les-decisions/depuis-1958/decisions-par-date/1962/62-20-dc/decision-n-62-20-dc-du-06-novembre-1962.6398.html decision 62-20 DC] from the Constitutional Council.</ref> This was unsurprising: from 1958 to 1970, under Charles de Gaulle's presidency, the Constitutional Council was sometimes described as a "cannon aimed at Parliament",<ref name="Stone"/> protecting the executive branch against encroachment by Parliament; all referrals except the one from Monnerville had come from the Prime Minister, who always got a ruling of partial unconstitutionality (the Council had struck down for unconstitutionality provisions introduced by Parliament that the Prime Minister disagreed with).<ref name="Stone"/> Monnerville went as far as to use the strong word of ''forfaiture'' ("abuse of authority") against the behaviour of Prime Minister Pompidou, who had accepted the referendum project.<ref name="conflit">[[French Senate]], ''[http://www.senat.fr/evenement/archives/D23/1962.html Le conflit du référendum de 1962]'' ("The conflict of the referendum of 1962")</ref><ref>[http://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/jopdf/common/jo_pdf.jsp?numJO=0&dateJO=19621003&pageDebut=09522&pageFin=&pageCourante=09522 Decree 62-1127 of 2 October 1962], preceded by a letter from Prime Minister [[Georges Pompidou]] to President Charles de Gaulle proposing him to submit to a referendum. following article 11 of the Constitution, a bill changing the method for electing the President of France.</ref>
Many members of the National Assembly were also very unhappy about the situation. On 4 October 1962, the Assembly [[vote of no-confidence|voted no-confidence in the Government]],<ref>Proceedings of the National Assembly, [http://archives.assemblee-nationale.fr/1/cri/1962-1963-ordinaire1/003.pdf 4 October 1962], second sitting; vote tally on p. 3268. p. 38 in the PDF file</ref> resulting in the automatic resignation of the Prime Minister (Constitution, article 49-2); this was the only successful vote of no-confidence of the Fifth Republic.<ref>[http://www.vie-publique.fr/decouverte-institutions/institutions/approfondissements/motion-censure-veritable-moyen-controle.html La motion de censure : véritable moyen de contrôle ?] ("The no-confidence vote: true means of control?")</ref> The vote was supported by, among others, former prime ministers<ref>More precisely: during the [[French Third Republic|Third]] and [[French Fourth Republic|Fourth Republic]], the position corresponding to the prime minister was known as ''Président du conseil des ministres'' ("president of the Council of ministers"), shortened to ''Président du conseil''.</ref> [[Paul Reynaud]] and [[Guy Mollet]], who severely criticized the referendum.<ref>See debates of the National Assembly on 4 October 1962: [http://archives.assemblee-nationale.fr/1/cri/1962-1963-ordinaire1/002.pdf first sitting], [http://archives.assemblee-nationale.fr/1/cri/1962-1963-ordinaire1/003.pdf second sitting].</ref> [[Charles de Gaulle]] dissolved the Assembly within a few days,<ref>[http://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/jopdf/common/jo_pdf.jsp?numJO=0&dateJO=19621010&numTexte=&pageDebut=09818&pageFin= Decree of 9 October 1962] dissolving the National Assembly</ref> thus provoking [[French legislative election, 1962|legislative elections in November]], and appointed Georges Pompidou again.
==Results== {| class=wikitable style=text-align:right !rowspan=2|Choice !colspan=2|[[Metropolitan France]] !colspan=2|Total |- !Votes !% !Votes !% |- |align=left|For||12,809,363||61.8||13,150,516||62.3 |- |align=left|Against||7,932,695||38.2||7,974,538||37.7 |- |align=left|Invalid/blank votes||559,758||–||569,509||– |- |align=left|'''Total'''||'''21,301,816'''||'''100'''||'''21,694,563'''||'''100''' |- |align=left|Registered voters||27,582,113||–||28,185,478||– |- |align=left colspan=6|Source: Nohlen & Stöver |}
==Aftermath== Since the referendum was positive, the mode of election of the president changed, and Charles de Gaulle remains the only president of France elected by an electoral college. Charles de Gaulle [[French presidential election, 1965|was reelected in 1965]], this time by direct suffrage.
==References== :''For references to constitutional articles, see the [http://www.assemblee-nationale.fr/english/8ab.asp official translation] of the Constitution on the site of the [[French National Assembly]].''
<references/>
==Further reading== *''Table ronde : la réforme de 1962'', with Gilles Le Béguec, Pierre Sudreau, [[Jean Donnedieu de Vabres]], [[Jean Foyer]], [[Jean-Marcel Jeanneney]], ''Parlement[s], Revue d'histoire politique'', [http://www.cairn.info/revue-parlements-2004-3.htm n° HS 1 2004/3], pp. 23–43, [[L'Harmattan]],

{{Infobox software license | name = GNU Lesser General Public License | image = File:LGPLv3 Logo.svg | caption = Logo | author = | version = 3 ({{Start date and age|2007}}) | publisher = | date = {{Start date and age|1991}} | OSI approved = Yes | Debian approved = Yes | FSF approved = Yes | GPL compatible = Yes | copyleft = Yes | linking = Yes | website = {{URL|https://www.gnu.org/copyleft/lesser.html}} }}
The '''GNU Lesser General Public License''' ('''LGPL''') is a [[free software license]] published by the [[Free Software Foundation]] (FSF). The license allows developers and companies to use and integrate software released under the LGPL into their own (even [[proprietary software|proprietary]]) software without being required by the terms of a strong [[copyleft]] license to release the source code of their own components. The license only requires software under the LGPL be modifiable by end users via source code availability. For proprietary software, code under the LGPL is usually used in the form of a [[shared library]], so that there is a clear separation between the proprietary and LGPL components. The LGPL is primarily used for [[Library (computing)|software libraries]], although it is also used by some stand-alone applications.
The LGPL was developed as a compromise between the strong [[copyleft]] of the [[GNU General Public License]] (GPL) and more [[Permissive free software licence|permissive]] licenses such as the [[BSD license]]s and the [[MIT License]]. The word "Lesser" in the title shows that the LGPL does not guarantee the end user's complete freedom in the use of software; it only guarantees the freedom of modification for components licensed under the LGPL, but not for any proprietary components.
==History== The license was originally called the '''GNU Library General Public License''' and was first published in 1991, and adopted the version number 2 for parity with GPL version 2. The LGPL was revised in minor ways in the 2.1 point release, published in 1999, when it was renamed the GNU Lesser General Public License to reflect the FSF's position that not all libraries should use it. Version 3 of the LGPL was published in 2007 as a list of additional permissions applied to GPL version 3.
==Differences from the GPL== The main difference between the GPL and the LGPL is that the latter allows the work to be linked with (in the case of a library, "used by") a non-(L)GPLed program, regardless of whether it is [[free software]] or [[proprietary software]].<ref name="not_use_LGPL">Stallman, Richard. [http://www.fsf.org/licensing/licenses/why-not-lgpl.html Why you shouldn't use the Lesser GPL for your next library]. [[Free Software Foundation]] official website.</ref> The non-(L)GPLed program can then be distributed under any terms if it is not a [[derivative work]]. If it is a derivative work, then the program's terms must allow for "modification for the customer's own use and [[reverse engineering]] for debugging such modifications." Whether a work that uses an LGPL program is a derivative work or not is a legal issue. A standalone executable that [[Library (computing)#Dynamic linking|dynamically links]] to a library through a [[Library (computing)#Shared libraries|.so]], [[Dynamic-link library|.dll]], or similar medium is generally accepted as not being a derivative work as defined by the LGPL. It would fall under the definition of a "work that uses the Library". Paragraph 5 of the LGPL version 2.1 states:
:A program that contains no derivative of any portion of the Library, but is designed to work with the Library by being compiled or linked with it, is called a "work that uses the Library". Such a work, in isolation, is not a derivative work of the Library, and therefore falls outside the scope of this License.
Essentially, if it is a "work that uses the library", then it must be possible for the software to be linked with a newer version of the LGPL-covered program. The most commonly used method for doing so is to use "a suitable [[Library (computing)#Shared libraries|shared library]] mechanism for linking". Alternatively, a [[statically linked library]] is allowed if either source code or linkable object files are provided.<ref name="LGPL_Section_4">[https://www.gnu.org/copyleft/lesser.html#section4 Gnu Lesser General Public License, Section 4], pt. d) 0)</ref>
==Compatibility== One feature of the LGPL is the permission to [[Software relicensing|relicense]] under the GPL any piece of software which is received under the LGPL (see section 3 of the LGPL version 2.1, and section 2 option b of the LGPL version 3). This feature allows for direct reuse of LGPLed code in GPLed libraries and applications.
Version 3 of the LGPL is not inherently compatible with version 2 of the GPL. However, works using the latter that have given permission to use a later version of the GPL are compatible:<ref name="LGPL_FSF">[https://www.gnu.org/licenses/license-list.html#LGPL GNU Lesser General Public License (LGPL) version 3]. [[Free Software Foundation]] official website.</ref> a work released under the GPLv2 "or any later version" may be combined with code from a LGPL version 3 library, with the combined work as a whole falling under the terms of the GPLv3.<ref name="LGPL_FSF_MATRIX">[https://www.gnu.org/licenses/gpl-faq.html#gpl-compat-matrix Frequently Asked Questions about the GNU Licenses - GNU Project - Free Software Foundation]. [[Free Software Foundation]] official website.</ref>
==LGPL for libraries== The former name "GNU Library General Public License" gave some the impression that the FSF recommended software libraries use the LGPL and that programs use the GPL. In February 1999, GNU Project leader Richard Stallman wrote the essay ''Why you shouldn't use the Lesser GPL for your next library'' explaining that the LGPL had not been [[deprecation|deprecated]], but that one should not ''necessarily'' use the LGPL for all libraries:
:Which license is best for a given library is a matter of strategy ... Using the ordinary GPL for a library gives free software developers an advantage over proprietary developers: a library that they can use, while proprietary developers cannot use it ... When a free library's features are readily available for proprietary software through other alternative libraries ... the library cannot give free software any particular advantage, so it is better to use the Lesser GPL for that library.<ref name="not_use_LGPL" />
Stallman and the FSF sometimes advocate licenses even less restrictive than the LGPL as a matter of strategy. A prominent{{cn|date=October 2018}} example was Stallman's endorsement of the use of a [[BSD license|BSD-style]] license by the [[Vorbis]] project for use in its libraries.<ref name="Vorbis_and_BSD">Stallman, Richard. [https://lwn.net/2001/0301/a/rms-ov-license.php3 <nowiki>Re: [open-source] [Fwd: [icecast-dev] Xiph.org announces Vorbis Beta 4 and the Xiph.org</nowiki>]</ref>
==Programming language specifications== The license uses terminology which is mainly intended for applications written in the [[C (programming language)|C programming language]] or its family. Franz Inc. published its own preamble to the license to clarify terminology in the [[Lisp (programming language)|Lisp]] context. LGPL with this preamble is sometimes referred as LLGPL.<ref name="LGPL_preamble">[http://opensource.franz.com/preamble.html Preamble to the Gnu Lesser General Public License]</ref>
In addition, [[Ada (programming language)|Ada]] has a special feature, [[wikibooks:Ada Programming/Generics|generics]], which may prompt the use of [[GNAT Modified General Public License]]: it allows code to link against or instantiate GMGPL-covered units without the code itself becoming covered by the GPL.
[[C++]] templates and [[Header-only|header-only libraries]] have the same problem as Ada generics. Version 3 of the LGPL addresses such cases in section 3.<ref>[https://listengine.tuxfamily.org/lists.tuxfamily.org/eigen/2008/02/msg00003.html LGPLv3 for a C++ Pure Template Library ?]</ref>
===Class inheritance=== Some concern has risen about the suitability of object-oriented classes in LGPL'd being [[Inheritance (computer science)|inherited]] by non-(L)GPL code. Clarification is given on the official GNU website:
:The LGPL does not contain special provisions for inheritance, because none are needed. Inheritance creates derivative works in the same way as traditional linking, and the LGPL permits this type of derivative work in the same way as it permits ordinary function calls.<ref>Turner, David. [https://www.gnu.org/licenses/lgpl-java.html The LGPL and Java]. [[GNU]] official website.</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Free software}} <!-- Please keep entries in alphabetical order & add a short description [[WP:SEEALSO]] --> *[[Affero General Public License]] *[[GNU Free Documentation License]] *[[GNAT Modified General Public License]] *[[GPL linking exception]] *[[:Category:Software using the LGPL license|Software using the LGPL (category)]] <!-- please keep entries in alphabetical order -->

[[File:Gibson & Weldon advertisement, 1911.jpg|thumb|1911 advertisement for three of Gibson and Weldon's law books]] '''Gibson and Weldon''' was a law practice at 27 [[Chancery Lane]] in London and the name of its tutorial firm which from 1876 until 1962 prepared hundreds of thousands of future [[solicitor]]s and [[barrister]]s in England and Wales for their examinations.''International Bar Journal'' (November 1973). [http://heinonline.org/HOL/LandingPage?handle=hein.barjournals/intbrjrnl0004&div=36&id=&page= "Book Review: ''Gibson's, 1876–1962: A chapter in legal education''"], p. 133. Gibson and Weldon also published the monthly journal ''Law Notes'' and a series of legal textbooks from adjacent offices at 25–26 Chancery Lane. The firm's principles were Albert Gibson (1852–1921) and Arthur William Weldon (1856–1943). After the death of Arthur Weldon the tutorial firm continued until 1962 when it was merged with the [[Law Society of England and Wales|Law Society]]'s own law school to form the College of Law (since 2013 known as the [[University of Law]]). ==History== The latter part of the 19th century saw the introduction of formal examinations for entry into the legal profession. From 1862 solicitors were required to pass the Intermediate and Preliminary Examinations set by the Law Society, and later a prestigious Honours Examination was introduced. Compulsory written examinations for barristers were introduced in 1872. The university law schools concentrated on the principles, as opposed to the practice, of the law and found it increasingly difficult to sustain courses which could provide the practical knowledge required to pass the examinations. The Council of Legal Education, established by the [[Inns of Court]] in 1852, had the same problem.Abel, (1998). [https://books.google.com/books?id=JTfRrksqNMQC&pg=PA536 ''The Making of the English Legal Profession 1800–1988''], pp. 50; 145–146. Beard Books (reprint of the 1988 edition). {{ISBN|1587982501}} This in turn led to the rise of specialist tutorial firms which legal historian Patricia Leighton has termed "the first professional law teachers."Leighton, Patricia (2014). [http://sections.legalscholars.ac.uk/papers/download.cfm?id=354 "Who were the first professional law teachers? An historical investigation"]. Paper presented at the [[Society of Legal Scholars]] Conference, Nottingham 2014. Retrieved 12 June 2016. The firms were largely established and run by practicing attorneys in London. The tension arising in the profession between the systems followed by the university law schools and those of the tutorial firms had sometimes led them to be dismissed as "[[crammer]]s". It was a tension reflected in Gibson and Weldon's own 1905 advertisement stating that their "system of student preparation is as far as possible that of a Law School and all idea of preparing students on a 'cram' system is disregarded."Quoted in Leighton (2014) p. 14{{efn|In 1929, while still an undergraduate at Cambridge, [[Mohammad Hidayatullah]], the future [[Chief Justice of India]], applied to Gibson and Weldon to prepare him for the barrister examination in six weeks. The firm refused, writing to him "we do not work miracles."Hidayatullah, Mohammad (2010). [https://books.google.com/books?id=31nqgwKuK3sC&pg=PA54 ''Law in the Scientific Era''], p. 54. Universal Law Publishing (reprint of the 1981 edition). {{ISBN|8175342609}}.}} Over 60 years after the firm's founding, the British jurist [[R. M. Jackson]] wrote in ''The Machinery of Justice in England'':
I was in my time a pupil of Gibson and Weldon and I received better training from Mr. Weldon than I ever had in Cambridge, and by that I do not mean just the know-how to pass examinations but a real insight into the ways of lawyers and the courts.Stevens, Robert Bocking (January 1969). [https://www.jstor.org/stable/1339408 "''The Machinery of Justice in England'' by R. M. Jackson"]. ''[[Harvard Law Review]]'', Vol. 82, No. 3, p. 722. Retrieved via [[JSTOR]] 12 June 2016 {{subscription}}.
Gibson and Weldon began in 1876 when Albert Gibson who had qualified as a solicitor in the Easter 1874 Honours examination began advertising for pupils who needed coaching for the Law Society examinations. In 1881, he was joined by the newly qualified Arthur Weldon who had been one of his first pupils.[https://books.google.com/books?id=TOIyAAAAIAAJ&dq=gibson+weldon+solicitors&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=spent ''Graya: A Magazine for Members of Gray's Inn''] (1957). Volume 10, p. 102 By the end of the 19th century, Gibson and Weldon, along with Indermaur and Thwaites,{{efn|The principles of Indermaur and Thwaites were [[John Indermaur]] (1852–1925) and Charles Thwaites who qualified as a solicitor in 1880, six years after Indermaur. Their firm was located at 22 Chancery Lane.Indermaur, John and Thwaites, Charles (1886). [https://archive.org/details/studentsguidetos00inde ''The Student's Guide to Specific Performance and Mortgages''] ([[front matter]]). G. Barber.}} dominated the law tutorial market in the UK. The two firms also dominated the law publishing market. January 1882 saw the first edition of ''Gibson's Law Notes'', a monthly magazine for law students which originally published model answers and study advice for the Law Society examinations and other articles of interest to the legal profession. In 1885 it became simply ''Law Notes'' and remained in publication until the mid-1990s, long after Gibson and Weldon had ceased existence as a tutorial firm. Gibson and Weldon also published guides to the profession such as ''How to Become a Barrister'' and ''How to Become a Solicitor'' and numerous student-centered text books which were frequently updated in multiple editions. Their text book on [[conveyancing]], first published in 1888 ran to 21 editions, the last of which was published in 1980.{{OCLC|499718708}} For a time Edward Power Bilbrough was a partner in their practice at 27 Chancery Lane and also co-authored a textbook on the Companies Act of 1900 with Gibson and Weldon.{{efn| Edward Power Bilbrough later married Mary Lewis, an actress and the sister of [[Lewis Waller]].''The Law Times'' (1909). "Marriages", Vol. 126, p. 70.}} However, he left to form his own practice in 1901, and Gibson, Weldon and Bilbrough once again became Gibson and Weldon.''[[London Gazette]]'' (7 January 1902). [https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/27395/page/179/data.pdf "Gibson, Weldon, and Bilborough"], p. 179 Over the years, several other lawyers joined the firm as tutors and as authors of their teaching materials. These included Gibson's godson Henry Gibson Rivington (1872–1954), Arthur Clifford Fountaine (1875–1931) and Hermon Joseph Bond Cockshutt (1907–1970). In addition to their taught courses, which normally consisted of three months of intensive teaching, Gibson and Weldon also ran correspondence courses for [[articled clerk]]s working outside London or unable to take time off work to attend in person. [[Quintin Hogg, Baron Hailsham of St Marylebone|Lord Hailsham]] studied for all his examinations in the early 1930s via their correspondence courses.Hogg, Quintin (1990). ''A Sparrow's Flight: The Memoirs of Lord Hailsham of St Marylebone'', p. 70. HarperCollins. {{ISBN|0002155451}} In 1931, ten years after the death of Albert Gibson, the firm was incorporated as a [[limited liability company]], Gibson and Weldon (Law Tutors) Ltd.{{efn|Despite its merger into the College of Law in 1962, Gibson and Weldon (Law Tutors) Ltd. was not formally dissolved until 2013.[[Companies House]]. [https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/company/00259519 Company number 00259519]. Retrieved 13 June 2016.}} In 1961 the company was acquired by the Law Society, whose own law school was one of their competitors. The following year, the society merged the two schools into the College of Law with branches in London and [[Guildford]]. Hermon Cockshutt, an expert on tax law and the senior partner in Gibson and Weldon after the death of Arthur Weldon in 1943, had been instrumental in the negotiations leading to the firm's acquisition by the Law Society. He became the Deputy Chairman of the Board of the newly formed college.''[[Law Society Gazette]]'' (1970). "Hermon Joseph Bond Cockshutt", Vol 10, p. 269 [[John Widgery, Baron Widgery|John Widgery]], the future [[Lord Chief Justice of England and Wales]], was another of Gibson and Weldon's tutors who continued teaching at the newly formed college.''Law Notes'' (1981). "Lord Widgery". Vol. 100, No. 9, p. 226. Quote: "Lord Widgery never lost touch with his legal roots: he maintained contact with his former colleagues at Gibson's and subsequently with the College of Law." Richard Antony Donell (1923–2006), the last of the former partners of Gibson and Weldon on the staff of the College of Law, retired in 1988. Donell had prepared and updated the 21st and final edition of ''Gibson's Conveyancing''.''Law Notes'' (1988). "R. A. Donell", Vol. 107, No. 7, p. 170 ==Former pupils== Former pupils of Gibson and Weldon include: {{Div col}} *[[Robin Day]] (1923–2000), British political broadcaster and former barrister *[[David de Caires]] (1937–2008), [[Guyana|Guyanese]] solicitor; founder and Editor-in-Chief of ''[[Stabroek News]]''.''[[Stabroek News]]'' (10 December 2008). [http://www.stabroeknews.com/2008/guyana-review/12/10/david-de-caires-man-mission-and-the-media/ "David de Caires: Man, mission and the media"]. Retrieved 13 June 2016. *[[Robin Dunn]] (1918–2014), [[High Court of Justice]] and [[Lord Justice of Appeal]] from 1980 to 1984Dunn, Robin (1993). ''Sword and Wig: Memoirs of a Lord Justice'', p. 103. Quiller Press. {{ISBN|1870948882}} *[[William R. P. George]] (1912-2006), Welsh solicitor and poet''[[Daily Telegraph]]'' (5 December 2006). [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1536002/WRP-George.html Obituary: WRP George"]. Retrieved 13 June 2016. *[[Quintin Hogg, Baron Hailsham of St Marylebone|Quintin Hogg, Lord Hailsham]] (1907–2001), [[Lord High Chancellor of Great Britain]] from 1979 to 1987 *[[R. M. Jackson]] (1903–1986), British jurist and legal scholar *[[Seretse Khama]] (1921–1980), the first president of [[Botswana]]Williams, Susan (2007). [https://books.google.com/books?id=a3Wt48ldWm0C&pg=PR4-IA3 ''Colour Bar: The triumph of Seretse Khama and His Nation''], p. 193. Penguin. {{ISBN|014190092X}} *[[Idris Legbo Kutigi]] (1939–), [[Chief Justice of Nigeria]] from 2007 to 2009Court of Appeal Nigeria. [http://www.courtofappeal.com.ng/index.php?option=com_content&view=category&id=81&Itemid=485 Former Chief Justices of Nigeria]. Retrieved 14 June 2016. *[[Robert Megarry]] (1910–2006), [[Vice-Chancellor of the Supreme Court]] from 1982 to 1985Merriman, Nicholas (25 October 2006). [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/sir-robert-megarry-6230441.html "Sir Robert Megarry; Long-lived judge of profound learning and epigrammatic wit"]. ''[[The Independent]]''. Retrieved 13 June 2016. *[[Ronald Waterhouse]] (1926–2011), [[High Court of Justice]] from 1978 to 1996Waterhouse, Ronald (2013). [https://books.google.com/books?id=Hgj4AgAAQBAJ&pg=PT59 ''Child of Another Century: Recollections of a High Court Judge''], p. 59. The Radcliffe Press. {{ISBN|0857733141}} *[[Stephen Yong Kuet Tze]] (1921–2001), [[Malaysia]]n politician; Secretary-General of the [[Sarawak United Peoples' Party]] from 1959 to 1982.Yong Kuet Tze, Stephen (1998). ''A life twice lived'', p. 70. S. Yong. {{ISBN|983994570X}} {{Div col end}} ==Notes== {{Notelist}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== *Kersley, Robert Henry (1973). ''Gibson's, 1876-1962: A chapter in legal education''. Law Notes Library (an illustrated history of the firm written by one of its former tutors, with a foreword by [[John Widgery, Baron Widgery|Lord Widgery]]) *Leighton, Patricia (2015). [http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/09695958.2015.1119027?journalCode=cijl20 "The LLB as a liberal degree? A re-assessment from an historical perspective"]. ''International Journal of the Legal Profession'', Vol. 22, Issue 1, pp. 87–102 (a detailed critique of the texts and study materials developed by Gibson and Weldon and other tutorial firms, subscription required) ==External links== *[http://worldcat.org/identities/lccn-n82217411/ Gibson, Albert 1852-1921] on [[WorldCat]] *[http://worldcat.org/identities/lccn-n85351985/ Weldon, Arthur 1856-1943] on WorldCat *[https://archive.org/search.php?query=creator%3A%22Gibson%2C+Albert%2C+1852-1921%22 Three complete law books by Gibson and Weldon] on the [[Internet Archive]] [[Category:Law firms established in 1876]] [[Category:Law firms disestablished in the 20th century]] [[Category:Law firms based in London]] [[Category:Legal education in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Legal educators]] [[Category:Legal publishers]]

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{citation style|date=October 2018}} {{one source|date=October 2018}} {{copy edit|date=October 2018}} }}
{{more citations needed|date=October 2018}}
<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.loc.gov/law/foreign-news/article/japan-act-on-specified-commercial-transactions-amended/|title=Japan: Act on Specified Commercial Transactions Amended {{!}} Global Legal Monitor|date=2016-08-29|website=www.loc.gov|language=en|others=Umeda, Sayuri|access-date=2018-10-20}}</ref> The '''Japan Act of Specified Commercial Transactions''' ([[:JA:特定商取引に関する法律|特定商取引法]]) is described and explained in a publication by the [[Consumer Affairs Agency|Japan Consumer Affairs Agency(JCAA)]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Consumer Affairs Agency, Understanding the Act of Specified Commercial Transactions (Japanese) 消費者庁 |title=平成28年版 特定商取引に関する法律の解説 |date=2016 |publisher=商事法務 |location=Japan |isbn=978-4785726478}}</ref> It is a Japanese law whose main aim is to protect consumers from harm and to ensure fairness in transactions such as [[Door-to-door|Door-to-door sales]] as these are prone to conflicts between consumers and companies. In particular, with the aim of solving or avoiding such conflicts, it includes regulations on the act of soliciting.<ref name="page 3"/>
==Background of Law Enactment== During the 1970s, [[Japan]] experienced an increase in consumer demand and product diversity. Various methods of communication, transportation and delivery became available and competition among retailers intensified. Many of them began to look for ways to increase their customer base by selling at places other than shops. New methods of selling products, such as [[Door-to-door|door-to-door sales]] and [[mail order]], began to appear.<ref name="page3">Consumer Affairs Agency, p. 3</ref> However, ethical standards had not yet been put in place for this new industry, and consumers were not accustomed to these new vending approaches. In many cases, these were the only points of contact between consumers and businesses, and conflicts occurring later on, could not be easily resolved. These conflicts started increasing.<ref name="page3" /> Also, during the second half of the 1960s, unethical use of [[Multi-level marketing|Multi-level Marketing]] was deemed by lawmakers to cause social problems.<ref name="page 3" /> To handle these social problems and conflicts, the Act of Specified Commercial Transactions was enacted in 1976 at the 77th assembly of the [[National Diet|National Diet of Japan]].<ref name="page4">Ibid, p. 4</ref>
==Contents of the Act== This Japanese law mainly pertains to commercial transactions such as:
* [[Door-to-door|Door-to-door sales]] * [[Mail order|Mail order sales]] * [[Telemarketing]] * [[Multi-level marketing|Multi-Level Marketing (MLM)]].
==Articles of the Act pertaining to Multi-Level Marketing (MLM)== As of June 2016, Japanese Laws pertaining to [[Multi-level marketing|Multi-Level Marketing (MLM)]] are stated in Articles 33 to 40. Some Regulations from Articles 33, 34 and 36 Regarding Multi-level Marketing (MLM) are outlined below;
===1. Coordinator's Name Must Be Stated=== According to Article 33 Part 2, it is prohibited to solicit without first stating the nature of the MLM business and the coordinator’s name.<ref name="page242" />
; Explanation:
There have been cases of MLM solicitors visiting someone’s house, organizing a house party or some alumni reunion, and not being truthful about the purpose of their visit.<ref name="page242">Ibid, p. 242</ref> Those solicitors then skillfully talk people into signing up for MLM, and many cases, people sign up for MLM without knowing about the financial burden they are getting themselves into.<ref name="page242" /> Essentially, people are being solicited in spite of the fact that they may not have wanted to be solicited in the first place. Many people may not wish to be solicited perhaps because they have no interest in MLM or are too busy to devote time for MLM. When solicitors visit someone without first announcing the true purpose of the visit, they deny that person the chance to consider if he or she even wants to be solicited in the first place.<ref name="page242" /> The purpose of Article 33 Part 2 is to protect the interests of people who may not wish to be solicited.<ref name="page242" />
Solicitors must announce from the start the company name and the name of their coordinator. Further, people who are not familiar with MLM might not realize what kind of business they are about to be solicited for. Thus, solicitors must also announce from the start the amount of money involved. More precisely, solicitors must begin with a statement such as: "I would like to recruit you for some business in which you will buy (exact amount of money) of health supplements, would you be interested?"<ref name="page244">Ibid, p. 244</ref>
===2. False Claims regarding Prospects of Income=== According to Article 34, it is prohibited to misrepresent facts or make false claims regarding prospects of income.<ref name="page249" />
; Explanation:
It is illegal to misrepresent facts or make false claims regarding the prospects of making money with MLM. For example, if there is no absolute guarantee of making a certain amount of money, making statements suggesting otherwise amounts to making false claims. Such false claims include statements such as: "If you join this business, you will make a monthly income in the seven figures", "If you do this business for one month you will make more money than a white-collar worker does".<ref name="page249">Ibid, p. 249</ref>
The following three cases also amount to making false claims:<ref name="page249" />
* a) Telling people only about a few rare cases of successful MLM distributors and failing to mention the difficulty and low possibility of achieving the high income of such successful MLM distributors.<ref name="page249" /> * b) Telling people "This is not Multi-level Marketing"<ref name="page249" /> * c) Telling people "This business falls under a category approved by the Ministry of Japan.<ref name="page249" />
===3. No Soliciting on a Private Property=== According to Article 34 Section 4, soliciting on private property is prohibited without first declaring one’s true intent.<ref name="page251" />
; Explanation:
There have been cases of people signing up for MLM without really intending to, for they were unable to make an informed decision or use rational judgment, partly because they felt cornered by a solicitor who entered a private property without first announcing the intent to solicit.<ref name="page251">Ibid, p. 251</ref> A legal amendment of 2008 now prohibits such act or behaviour.<ref name="page251" /> Examples of private property include the office of a company, someone’s house, a hotel room, the meeting room of a hotel, the meeting room of a public facility, a karaoke room, and a restaurant rented for a private group for the evening.<ref name="page252">Ibid, p. 252</ref> Further, to begin soliciting in a public space and continue soliciting in a private property also constitutes an act in violation of Article 34.<ref name="page252" /> As soon as someone solicits in a private property, he or she is in violation of Article 34.<ref name="page252" /> Offenders found in violation of Article 34 face a fine of up to 3 million yen and/or a sentence of up to 3 years in jail.<ref name="page252" />
===4. No e-mailing Multi-level Marketing ads=== According to Article 36 Part 3, it is prohibited to advertise Multi-level Marketing through e-mail without prior written consent from the e-mail recipient.<ref name="page260">Ibid, p. 260</ref>
== Notes == {{Reflist}}

{{italictitle}} {{More citations needed|date=March 2010}} '''''Jure uxoris''''' is a [[Latin]] phrase meaning "by right of (his) wife".<ref>In Latin, ''jure'' is the [[ablative case]] of ''jus'', meaning a legal right.</ref><ref>{{Citation | first = HC | last = Black | title = Law Dictionary | edition = 4th | year = 1968}}, citing {{Citation | last = Blackstone | title = Commentaries | volume = 3 | page = 210}}.</ref> When a man uses a title of [[nobility]] because his wife holds it ''[[suo jure]]'' ("in her own right"), the man is said to hold the title ''jure uxoris''. Similarly, the husband of an heiress could become the legal possessor of her lands. For example, married women in England were legally incapable of owning real estate until the [[Married Women's Property Act 1882]].
Kings who ruled ''jure uxoris'' are not to be confused with [[King consort|kings consort]], who were merely consorts of their wives, not co-rulers.{{citation needed|date=November 2017}}
==Middle Ages== During the feudal era, the husband's control over his wife's real property, including titles, was substantial. At the point of marriage, the husband gained the right to possess his wife's land during the marriage, including any acquired after the marriage.<ref name="Emanuel">{{cite book|title=Property |last=Emanuel |first=Steven L. |date=2004 |publisher=Aspen Publishers, inc. |location=New York |pages=121}}</ref> Whilst he did not gain the formal legal title to the lands, he was able to spend the rents and profits of the land and sell his right, even if the wife protested.<ref name="Emanuel" />
The concept of ''jure uxoris'' was standard in the [[Middle Ages]] even for [[Queen regnant|queens regnant]]. In the [[Kingdom of Jerusalem]], [[Fulk, King of Jerusalem]], [[Guy of Lusignan]], [[Conrad of Montferrat]], [[Henry II, Count of Champagne]] and [[Amalric II of Jerusalem]] all received their titles as a result of marriage.
[[Sigismund of Luxembourg]] married Queen [[Mary of Hungary]] and obtained the crown through her, retaining it after her death. After the death of Sigismund, [[Albert II, King of the Romans|Albert II of Austria]] inherited the throne of Hungary by marrying the king's daughter [[Elizabeth of Luxembourg]].
A king ''jure uxoris'' could remain king even after the death or divorce of his wife. When the marriage of [[Marie I of Boulogne]] and [[Matthew of Boulogne]] was annulled in 1170, Marie ceased to be countess, while Matthew I continued to reign until 1173. In some cases, the kingdom could pass to the husband's heirs, even when they were not issue of the wife in question (cf. [[Jogaila]], who became king by marrying [[Jadwiga of Poland|Jadwiga]] and passed on the kingdom to his children with [[Sophia of Halshany]]).
Kings ''jure uxoris'' in the medieval era include: *[[Rudolph of France]], whose wife [[Emma of France|Emma]] was daughter of King [[Robert I of France]] *[[Philip IV of France|Philip I of Navarre]], who was married to [[Joan I of Navarre]] *[[Frederick II, Holy Roman Emperor|Frederick]], who was named [[King of Jerusalem]] by virtue of his marriage to [[Isabella II of Jerusalem]] *[[Louis I of Naples]], whose wife was [[Joanna I of Naples]] *[[Philip III of Navarre]], who was married to [[Joan II of Navarre]] *[[John I of Castile]], who was a claimant to the throne of Portugal by virtue of his marriage to [[Beatrice of Portugal]]
==Renaissance== By the time of the [[Renaissance]], attitudes had changed in some countries: a woman sometimes remained monarch, with only part of her power transferred to her husband. This was usually the case when multiple kingdoms were consolidated, such as when [[Catholic Monarchs|Isabella and Ferdinand]] shared crowns.
The precedent of ''jure uxoris'' complicated the lives of [[Henry VIII of England|Henry VIII]]'s daughters, both of whom inherited the throne in their own right. The marriage of [[Mary I of England|Mary I]] to [[Philip II of Spain|King Philip]] was commonly seen as an attempt to bring England under the influence of Catholic Spain, with the [[Act for the Marriage of Queen Mary to Philip of Spain]] being designed specifically to prevent Philip from seizing power ''jure uxoris''. This tactic in the end ensured [[Elizabeth I of England|Elizabeth I]]'s accession; she, in turn, resolved concerns over ''jus uxoris'' by never marrying. In Navarre, [[Jeanne d'Albret]] had married [[Antoine de Bourbon|Antoine of Navarre]] in 1548, and she became queen regnant at her father's death in 1555. Antoine was crowned co-ruler ''jure uxoris'' with Jeanne in August.
==Partial transference of power== In Great Britain, husbands acted on their wives' behalf in the [[House of Lords]], from which women were once barred. These offices were exercised ''jure uxoris''.
When [[Priscilla Bertie, 21st Baroness Willoughby de Eresby|Lady Priscilla Bertie]] inherited the title [[Baron Willoughby de Eresby|Baroness Willougby de Eresby]] in 1780, she also held the position of [[Lord Great Chamberlain]]. However, her husband [[Peter Burrell, 1st Baron Gwydyr|Sir Peter Gwydyr]] acted on her behalf in that office instead.
==Conditions== In Portugal, a male consort could not become a king ''jure uxoris'' until the [[queen regnant]] had a child and royal heir. Although [[Maria II of Portugal|Queen Maria II]] married her second husband in 1836, Ferdinand of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha did not become [[Ferdinand II of Portugal|King Ferdinand II]] until 1837, when their first child was born. Queen Maria's first husband, [[Auguste de Beauharnais, 2nd Duke of Leuchtenberg|Auguste of Beauharnais]], never became monarch, because he died before he could father an heir. The queen's child did not have to be born after her accession. For example, [[Maria I of Portugal|Queen Maria I]] already had children by her husband when she acceded, so he became [[Peter III of Portugal|King Peter III]] at the moment of his wife's accession.
{{citation needed span|Currently in Spain, the husband of a peeress in her own right may use his wife's title socially|date=July 2016}}, although he is not technically entitled to it under the law. For example, [[Jaime de Marichalar]] was often referred to as the Duke of Lugo during his marriage to [[Infanta Elena, Duchess of Lugo]]. After their divorce, he ceased to use the title. His brother-in-law [[Iñaki Urdangarin]] was referred to as the Duke of Palma before corruption allegations prompted the King to take action. Since 12 June 2015, he is no longer referred to as the Duke of Palma de Mallorca, following the removal of that title from his wife, [[Infanta Cristina]].
==See also== * ''[[Jure matris]]'' * [[List of Latin phrases]]
